awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Increasing Access to Sustainable Freshwater Resources with Membrane Capacitive Deionization
awd_abstract_narration:
1605290
Cusick

Waters that are salty, not to the extent that sea water is, present a new source of water for beneficial use in many areas and cost efficient methods for treating them are a high priority. The proposed research and educational activities will advance the sustainability of brackish (salty) groundwater and reclaimed wastewater desalination by establishing an integrated multi-scale modeling and experimental framework for capacitive desalination technologies. Research will pursue financially viable desalination strategies with renewable carbon resources and will focus on overcoming knowledge gaps that limit our ability to design energy efficient and cost effective membrane capacitive deionization systems. This framework will be leveraged to teach undergraduates and high school students about water scarcity, sustainable water management and freshwater production through desalination. 

Reducing the energy intensity of freshwater production, while increasing water recovery, from reclaimed and saline sources will be critical to minimizing economic costs and environmental impacts. The overall goal of this work is to increase access to renewable freshwater resources in water stressed regions by addressing existing economic and energetic barriers to brackish and reclaimed water desalination. By coupling freshwater and brine production to capacitor electrode charging and discharging respectively, membrane capacitive deionization systems have the potential to remove ions from water near the thermodynamic limit of desalination, requiring far less energy than reverse osmosis. Producing potable water from low salinity sources (i.e., brackish water and reclaimed wastewater) is currently economically infeasible in most areas due to energy, maintenance and brine disposal costs of reverse osmosis. This research seeks to address critical barriers currently limiting membrane capacitive deionization, a potentially low cost and sustainable alternative to reverse osmosis, by developing novel electrode geometries and operating schemes within an integrated modeling and quantitative sustainable design framework that links microstructure composition, reactor design and operation decisions to predictions of treatment efficacy, freshwater production costs and environmental sustainability. The hypothesis is that capacitor-based deionization may enable energy efficient and cost effective production of freshwater from brackish and reclaimed water. The objectives of this proposed work are: i) to uncover mechanisms of electrochemical energy loss in membrane capacitive deionization systems through integrated modeling and experimentation; ii) to develop novel high performance electrode morphologies that address major energy loss mechanisms; iii) to develop a membrane capacitive deionization process model calibrated to the limits of technology for energy and water recovery; and, iv) to establish a path forward for membrane capacitive deionization development by integrating the process model into a quantitative sustainable design framework that integrates environmental, economic, and performance metrics under uncertainty.

por.por_cntn:
This work seeks to advance technologies that leverage electric double layer capacitors to removing salt from brackish groundwater, also known as capacitive deionization. As the capacitor is charged by passing electrical current to polarize the electrodes, ions are stored near the electrode surface. Provided enough surface area for ion storage, saline water can be converted to drinking water as energy is stored. At full scale, it can be envisioned that this process could alleviate both water stress and renewable energy storage in arid climates such as the southwestern United States. While significant advances have been made in the development of energy storage devices, the material properties and operating strategies necessary to enable cost and energy efficient desalination with capacitors remains poorly defined.

This project included experiments and modeling to better understand the factors driving the full-scale performance of the integrated process in which both energy is stored and water is desalinated. Key outcomes from this work include the development of models that can be used to predict the energy storage efficiency and salt removal capacity of capacitive deionization systems based on material properties and operating strategies. The most significant outcomes stemmed from experiments and modeling of an emerging process – membrane capacitive deionization. This process includes membranes with fixed chemical charge to control the flow of salt ions into and out of the capacitor electrodes and improve desalination efficiency. One of the challenges in scaling-up and commercializing the process, however, has been a lack of understanding of how these membranes impact energy storage and the project full-scale system cost. Through our experiments and modeling, we developed modeling tools to predict cost of water production for capacitive deionization systems with and without membranes. This new model, along with others that were updated and refined during the project, were then used to determine how best to advance capacitive technologies to produce cost-competitive desalinated water. Ultimately, we demonstrated why ion exchange membranes are important to performance but can cost prohibitive for desalination. We then used these models to inform the design of capacitors, showing how modifications in chemical composition and architecture can potentially eliminate the need for costly membranes.   

In addition to research outcomes, this project also contributed to the training of a number of graduate and undergraduate students, and the development of oursework curricula to facilitate engagement across the educational spectrum. More specifically, educational modules leveraging this general approach – using electroactive materials for energy storage and water treatment – have been developed and integrated into undergraduate courses. Additionally, hands on physical and chemical water treatment exercises were developed and piloted in elementary and middle schools to increase awareness of the engineered water cycle and foster affinity for environmental science and water treatment technology.
